instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.ISL6269: What is ISL6269? This is a typo of ISL6259.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hello. Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here that got fried by knockoff charger. <CHIP>ISL6269</CHIP> was fried, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> also fried. SMC is fried like KFC. I replaced ISL, replaced both mosfets and verified all current sensing resistors near ISL. Also replaced <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> as they looked suspicious. At the present moment I got SMC out of the board and am working on establishing at least 12.24V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line. My readings are as follows:

Got 16.5V from charger DCIN
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> varies from 0.3V to 2V after some time charger is connected, if I heat up <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> I get immediately 12.24V on L7030 and steady 3.3V on L6995. I'm stuck now. Tried injecting 12.5V on L7030, I get a sparkle but it does not drain any current from my PSU. Any ideas on what to look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
"Tried injecting 12.5V on L7030, I get a sparkle but it does not drain any current from my PSU"
Don't try to bypass charger stage in such way.
You still have to repair it, even the rest of board is OK (or not).

Start checking resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Also post some voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 19, 20.
Post exact value (ohm scale, measured onboard) for <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
17/18 = 2.4Ohm
27/28 = 20.5Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> = 98K
<RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> = 61.4K
<RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> = 465K
<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> = 331k

Voltages:

Pin 1 = 5mV
Pin 2 = 16.25V
Pin 3 = 3.86V
Pin 9 = 0V
Pin 12 = 228mV
Pin 13 = 229mV
Pin 14 = 228mV
Pin 15 = scaling up and down from 80mV to 400mV
Pin 19 = 5.06V
Pin 20 = 5.06V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
"Pin 12 = 228mV
Pin 13 = 229mV"
Do you miss 3V42???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 49249"]
Do you miss 3V42???[/QUOTE]

Yes, L6995 has 234mV

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Solve that problem.
Post diode mode to ground first.
If no short/low value, post <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages.
Check R/<DIODE>D6990</DIODE>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
I replaced <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> before posting here because they were blown... I found a short to GND on ISL and its two mosfets which I replaced. The short on <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> was cleared after replacing them and <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> is not blowing anymore. Voltages for <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>(already replaced it twice) are:

Pin 1 = 1.204V
Pin 2 = 3.64V
Pin 3 = 12.30V
Pin 4 = oscillating between 15.95V and 16.22V
Pin 5 = 0V
Pin 6 = 270mV
Pin 7 = oscillating between 15.90V and 16.22V
Pin 8 = 3.71V
Pin 9 = 313mV
Pin 10 = 0V

Diode mode to GND on L6995 is 0.324(red probe on ground, black on coil) and OL (red on coil, black on ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Did you change <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR>?
Also check all traces around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> has correct value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Yes, I checked <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR> and it's not shorted... <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> is 1Mohm... Will take another look under the microscope on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> area...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Apparently all traces are good... Verified with multimeter in beep mode and everything is going where it's supposed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Change <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Replaced it and still same voltage on L6995, 0.355V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Change again <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and be sure is properly soldered...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Replaced it... Same results... I'm thinking the knockoff charger fucked the board internally...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
How, if you didn't report any short?
Change L6995 now, or swap all pieces from similar board (same area).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: From the same area do you mean L6995 area? Will do it!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: I replaced L6995, <CAPACITOR>C7940</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3305</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>. Same readings...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
You miss something there.
If all changed, must get 3V42.
Post again diode mode on L6995 and all voltages for <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>...

Also compare diode mode (several points) and voltages with an working board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Diode mode(red on GND, black on L6995) = 0.331

Unfortunately I do not have a working board of the same model here to compare now... If someone here got any and could share readings would be nice!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages:

Pin1 = 1.215V
Pin2 = 3.61V
Pin3 = 12.47V
Pin4 = 16.84V
Pin5 = 0V
Pin6 = 0.457V
Pin7 = 16.83V
Pin8 = 3.6V
Pin9 = 275mV
Pin10 = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Now the thing got stranger! I re-soldered the SMC in place as I would give up and give this machine back to the costumer. When I reassembled the device, I put on the battery that had 60% of charge and on battery the machine powers on and I get beautiful 3.42V on L6995! The machine does not charge the battery though and neither gives green or orange light on charger, but this shit is working on battery now! What should be my next step?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Change R/<DIODE>D6990</DIODE>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Replaced both... Same results... Gave up on this one! Will give it back to costumer and move forward because the pile is getting bigger! Thanks for the help anyway.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
If the board works on battery only, then 3V42 power supply is OK.
You have a problem with the voltage coming from charger to 3V42 input...
